verses.text: So Israel set out with all he had and came to Beersheba, and he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
verses.comment: Jacob’s journey to Beersheba and offering sacrifices shows reverence for the covenant and continuity of true worship handed down from his ancestors. This foreshadows the importance of tradition and worship within the faith.

verses.text: And God spoke to Israel in a vision at night and said, 'Jacob, Jacob.' And he replied, 'Here I am.'
verses.comment: God’s personal call and Jacob’s obedient response mirrors the call of prophets and faithful servants throughout Scripture, hinting at the way divine calling is passed down through generations.

verses.text: He said, 'I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for there I will make you into a great nation.'
verses.comment: God’s promise echoes earlier covenants (Gen. 12:2). Egypt is both refuge and crucible for Israel’s growth. The fact that God reiterates the covenant family lineage highlights the deep continuity of God’s plan.

verses.text: 'I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also surely bring you back. And Joseph's hand will close your eyes.'
verses.comment: God assures His continued presence—an early form of divine accompaniment and guidance that finds fulfillment later in salvation history. The specific mention of Joseph gently closing Jacob's eyes connects family, care, and providence.

verses.text: Then Jacob set out from Beersheba. The sons of Israel carried Jacob their father, their little ones, and their wives in the wagons Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
verses.comment: The provision from Pharaoh illustrates divine favor working through secular authorities, prefiguring how God’s people are often sustained through unexpected means.

verses.text: They also took their livestock and the goods they had acquired in the land of Canaan and went to Egypt, Jacob and all his offspring with him.
verses.comment: Moving entire households and possessions marks the completeness of Israel’s relocation, a major turning point in God’s redemptive history.

verses.text: He brought with him to Egypt his sons and grandsons, his daughters and granddaughters—all his offspring.
verses.comment: All-inclusive language here emphasizes the fullness of the covenant family, foundational for the later identity of God’s people set apart and called together.

verses.text: Now these are the names of the sons of Israel, Jacob and his descendants, who went to Egypt: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn.
verses.comment: The genealogy here forms a direct line of tradition, important for both the physical and spiritual heritage of the chosen people.

verses.text: And the sons of Reuben: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
verses.comment: Listing the sons preserves the tribal structure for later divisions and inheritance, underscoring the corporate nature of God's covenant people.

verses.text: And the sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
verses.comment: Shaul’s mother being a Canaanite serves as a reminder of the early integration and the call to holiness distinct from surrounding nations.

verses.text: And the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.comment: Levi’s sons are ancestors of the priestly office, foreshadowing the unique role of sacred ministry and worship.

verses.text: And the sons of Judah: Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah—but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan. And the sons of Perez: Hezron and Hamul.
verses.comment: Judah’s line leads to the royal succession and ultimately to Jesus as Messiah (see Matthew 1:2-3), reinforcing the importance of covenant fidelity and lineage for future fulfillment.

verses.text: And the sons of Issachar: Tola, Puvah, Iob, and Shimron.
verses.comment: Issachar’s descendants contribute to the fullness of the twelve tribes, with each individual mentioned showing the thorough record-keeping of Scripture.

verses.text: And the sons of Zebulun: Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
verses.comment: Zebulun’s line further fortifies the tribal foundation for later inheritance and campaigns in Israel’s history.

verses.text: These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan-aram, together with his daughter Dinah. Altogether, his sons and daughters numbered thirty-three.
verses.comment: The mention of Dinah among the sons underlines the inclusiveness of all Jacob’s children. The sum total may reflect all immediate descendants, not counting grandchildren.

verses.text: And the sons of Gad: Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
verses.comment: Gad’s tribal genealogy would later help determine his blessings and territorial allotment in Israel’s history.

verses.text: And the sons of Asher: Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and their sister Serah. And the sons of Beriah: Heber and Malkiel.
verses.comment: Serah’s inclusion as a daughter hints at unique roles and records of women in Israel’s tradition, showing that God's redemption includes all.

verses.text: These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah, and she bore these to Jacob—sixteen persons.
verses.comment: The mention of servants and handmaids as integral members of the covenant people showcases how God’s plan works through all circumstances.

verses.text: The sons of Rachel, Jacob’s wife: Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.comment: Rachel’s position as wife, not just concubine, has theological implications for lineage—Joseph and Benjamin are central in later biblical history.

verses.text: And to Joseph in the land of Egypt were born Manasseh and Ephraim, whom Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, bore to him.
verses.comment: Joseph’s sons born from an Egyptian wife highlight the expansion of the covenant family to include Gentile bloodlines, foreshadowing the universal scope of salvation.

verses.text: And the sons of Benjamin: Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
verses.comment: The detailed list establishes Benjamin's tribe, later significant for the monarchy and the apostle Paul.

verses.text: These are the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob—fourteen persons in all.
verses.comment: A precise headcount shows the faithfulness of God’s promises through Rachel’s line, setting the stage for influence in Israel’s history.

verses.text: And the sons of Dan: Hushim.
verses.comment: Dan’s single descendant maintains the integrity of the tribal structure, even though limited.

verses.text: And the sons of Naphtali: Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
verses.comment: Naphtali’s family will play a role in later tribal assemblies and land inheritance within the promised land.

verses.text: These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel his daughter, and she bore these to Jacob—seven persons in all.
verses.comment: Again, handmaid's descendants are fully incorporated, showing God’s grace to unexpected members of the family.

verses.text: All the persons belonging to Jacob who came to Egypt—from his own offspring, not counting the wives of Jacob’s sons—were sixty-six persons in all.
verses.comment: The precise census underscores the careful stewardship and memory of God's people as they begin life in Egypt, drawing parallels to the later careful enumeration of the faithful in the new covenant.

verses.text: And the sons of Joseph, who were born to him in Egypt, were two persons. All the persons of the house of Jacob who came to Egypt were seventy.
verses.comment: The number seventy represents completeness and perfection, often symbolically important in both Testaments. See its echoes in the choosing of the seventy disciples (Luke 10:1).

verses.text: Jacob sent Judah ahead to Joseph to guide the way before him into Goshen, and they came into the land of Goshen.
verses.comment: Judah’s leadership foreshadows his tribe’s royal significance and hints at the importance of spiritual authority and guidance.

verses.text: Then Joseph made ready his chariot and went up to meet his father Israel in Goshen. He presented himself to him and fell on his neck and wept on his neck a long time.
verses.comment: Joseph’s embrace and tears demonstrate the depth of love and family reconciliation, mirroring the compassion and mercy of God to His people.

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, 'Now let me die, since I have seen your face and know that you are still alive.'
verses.comment: Seeing Joseph alive fulfills a longing. Jacob’s readiness to die now reflects spiritual completion, finding fulfillment in God’s provision.

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s household, 'I will go up and tell Pharaoh and will say to him, My brothers and my father’s household, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.'
verses.comment: Joseph acts as intercessor between his family and the king—a type and shadow of the High Priest going before the people, a theme picked up in later theology.

verses.text: 'The men are shepherds, for they have been keepers of livestock, and they have brought their flocks and herds and all that they possess.'
verses.comment: ‘Shepherds’ here recalls earlier biblical imagery of God as the true shepherd, and Israel as His flock—a theme dominant in the Psalms and the Gospels (John 10:11).

verses.text: 'And when Pharaoh calls you and asks, What is your occupation?'
verses.comment: Joseph prepares his brothers for their interaction with Pharaoh, demonstrating prudence and wise stewardship.

verses.text: 'You shall say, Your servants have been keepers of livestock from our youth until now, both we and our fathers, so that you may dwell in the land of Goshen—for every shepherd is abhorrent to the Egyptians.'
verses.comment: While shepherds are despised by Egyptians, their separateness actually preserves the chosen family's identity, just as spiritual separation helps maintain holiness and fidelity to God’s law.
